Walmart utilizes training programs from IIAR as well as RETA training protocol for their refrigeration technicians.  The programs consist of classroom training, viewing various training / safety videos and written testing procedures.  The training will be conducted on at least an annual basis.

4. THE RMP MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
The Maintenance Operations Manager will handle the management of the RMP program.  He/She will administrate in conjunction with the Walmart Perishable D.C. management and personnel.  Other entities or organizations that will be coordinated with include the Kern County Local Emergency Planning Region V Committee and the Shafter Fire Department.

5. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The Walmart Perishable D.C. facility complies with all applicable Federal, State and Local regulations including the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule.  Our personnel are trained about this during our Hazard Communications Training and through access to our written programs.  Our Refrigeration Maintenance operators receive a combination of classroom training plus On-The-Job (OJT) training. They are given written and oral tests and are observed and are able to demonstrate proper job skills and knowledge.  Also, the ammonia system is operated, tested and maintained to the standards of the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration, the most stringent standards of the industry.

6. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
This Walmart Perishable D.C. has onsite Hazardous Materials trained personnel to immediately respond to adverse conditions.  We have monthly meetings as well as an annual certification.  This helps to minimize the potential of an off-site release.
We work very closely with the Kern County Local Emergency Planning Region V Committee and the Shafter Fire Department on emergency preparedness.  We meet periodically with representatives of each to address any changes in the facility or any new concerns.

7. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Currently, this Walmart Perishable D.C. trains and tests all refrigeration technicians.  Our preventative maintenance program is above standard, and our total ammonia Process Safety Program is reviewed

Walmart 8852
Shafter, CA
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN Executive Summary

1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
At this Walmart Perishable Distribution Center (D.C.), we utilize anhydrous ammonia, which is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  The properties that make ammonia valuable as a refrigerant also necessitate certain safety precautions.  Walmart strives to protect all of its valuable resources and assets of both personnel and property.  We live and have families in this community.  We want to prevent exposure to all our personnel as well as nearby members of our community, existing natural resources, and the surrounding environment.  It is our policy to comply with all Federal, State and Local regulations.  Through continual, accurate training and various safety devices and procedures, we work to minimize potential releases.
Our emergency response program has specific procedures for accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia as well as other emergencies.  We work in conjunction with the Shafter Fire Department and the Kern County Local Emergency Planning Region V Committee to prepare for necessary notification of all effected neighbors.

2. THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGUALTED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The primary purpose of our facility is the temporary storage of refrigerated and frozen foods.  We utilize anhydrous ammonia as the primary means for refrigeration and freezing.  An outside company is used to fill our main receiver tanks.  Piping then carries the ammonia to the needed refrigeration and freezing units.  Access to the site is restricted to facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.
The regulated substance used at our facility is anhydrous ammonia.  The maximum amount of ammonia stored at this facility is 91,332 pounds.  We have the capacity for more, but our policy is to not exceed the IIAR recommendations of 80%.
